moves.1. e4: I do the King's Pawn opening...
moves.1... d5: ...and my opponent attacks my pawn in conjunction with the Scandinavian Defence...
moves.2... Qxd5: ...and my opponent captures mine, with the Lasker variation...
moves.3. Qf3: Now I chase the queen with mine...
moves.4... Qc5: Now she eyes up my c-pawn...
moves.5. Qe3: ...but what was I thinking, chasing her...
moves.6. Nc3: So I attempt to cage the queen by bringing up a knight...
moves.6... Nf6: ...my opponent also brings up a knight...
moves.7. Qg3: ...and I line up my opponent's c-pawn...
moves.8. Qc7: ...but I advance my queen to the 7th rank, anyway...
moves.8... Nbd7: ...an the other knight comes out, to save all three pieces...
moves.9. d3: ...so I cage the queen further by advancing my queen's pawn...
moves.9... Ng4: ...and as the knight advances closer, to eye up some of my pieces...
moves.10. Nh3: ...I read this by putting my knight on the rim to cover.
moves.10... Nc5: Now the other knight comes on the attack...
moves.11. f3: ...so I move up a pawn to attack its twin...
moves.11... Nxd3+: ...and as the knight attacks the king...
moves.12. Bxd3: ...I can capture it with my bishop...
moves.13. fxg4: ...and I can also remove the other knight...
moves.14. Qxb7: ...but capture back, and add some pressure to the rook with my queen...
moves.14... Rd8: ...forcing the rook to the only safe place...
moves.15. Qxc6+: ...allowing me to steal another pawn, and check the king...
moves.15... Bd7: ...and as the bishop blocks the check...
moves.16. Qe4: ...I now retreat my queen to attack my opponent's...
moves.16... Qxe4+: ...and I get what I was looking for, the queen captures mine...
moves.17. Nxe4: ...and I capture back, and remove the biggest threat.
moves.17... Bc6: The bishop lines up the capturing knight...
moves.18... f5: ...but my knight is now under attack from a pawn...
moves.19... Bxg2: ...and I lose a pawn to the bishop...
moves.20. Rg1: ..so my rook must move away from the corner...
moves.22. Nh4: ...so the knight retreats, and attacks the bishop...
moves.22... Bh5: ...so the bishop retreats to the edge...
moves.23. Ng4: ...and my other knight boxes it in, in the hope that it will capture my knight, and be captured by my rook...
moves.23... Rd4: ...but the rook comes down to attack from another side...
moves.24. Ne3: ...and I panic here, moving one knight out of the way...
moves.25. Rg2: So I move up my rook to cover the pawn...
moves.25... Re4: ..but my knight is pinned down by my opponent's rook...
moves.26... Bh6: ...and my opponent lines up another form of attack on my knight with the bishop...
moves.27. Rg3: ...so I cover my knight further with my rook...
moves.28. Rc1: ...but WHAT was I thinking, moving my other rook...
moves.28... Bxg3+: ...when its twin was clearly en prise? The bishop captures my rook, checking, and therefore distracting...
moves.29... O-O: My opponent castles to bring the other rook into play, and leave my king with nowhere to move...
moves.31. Nxc4: ...and I capture back with my knight.
moves.31... Rf3: The remaining rook advances to my 3rd rank...
moves.32. Bf4: ...so I put my bishop in front of it...
moves.32... Bg4: ...and as the bishop moves instead of the rook...
moves.35. Ne5: ...giving my knight a second bite of the cherry against the rook...
moves.35... g5: ...and as the pawn attacks my bishop...
moves.37. gxf4: ...but remove the pawn. In a game full of mistakes, I now have more of a foothold.
moves.37... Kf6 38. Kf2 Kf5 39. Kg3 Ke4 40. Nd: I move my knight to hope to fork two pawns...
moves.47... Kd5 48. Ng7: Now I eye up the other flank pawn...
moves.48... Kd6 49. Nxh5: ...and remove it, giving me a stranglehold.
moves.49... Ke6 50. Kg4 Kf7 51. Kg5 Kg8 52. Kg: I get my king in a position to be able to promote my pawn, and my opponent's only has one possible move...
moves.54. f5: ...allowing my pawn to move up, and keep the king on the h-file...
moves.63... Kb1 64. Qd2: ...and now she pins him to the a1 and b1 squares...
moves.64... Ka1 65. Kd6 Kb1 66. Kc5 Ka1 67. Kb: ...allowing my king to move in to help. My opponent resigned as there was only one move left: 68... Ka1, and I could have done 69. Qc1/Qd1/Qe1/Qa2/Qb2 for checkmate.
